Author: Rebecca Day

Article: Itâs early January and I should be making pre-dawn Starbucks runs before a marathon day, passing high rollers at baccarat tables who havenât closed the book on the previous night. But instead of covering the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas on throbbing feet, Iâm monitoring it from my home office New York. Due to Covid-19, CES, like nearly all conventions over the past 10 months or so, is being held virtually. My feet may be happy, but itâs just not the same without the bells and whistles. The Consumer Technology Association, which puts on CES, is doing what it can, using digital tools to host press conferences by marquee tech giants like LG, Samsung and Sony â and up-and-comers to the U.S. market like TCL and Skyworth â but CE gear and gadgets need to be seen and heard, even felt, to have full impact. Samsung returned to CES with its MicroLED display technology, dubbed The Wall. After years of it being a glimpse into the future, MicroLED is supposed to hit the market this year as a TV people can actually buy â all 110 inches of it. Now that is something Iâd like to see in person, but eying it from my 22-inch computer monitor is like trying to grasp the wonder of the Segovia Aqueduct from a 6.7-inch iPhone. You have to see it IRL to truly experience it. [Click on the image for a larger view]TCL says it will have 85-inch 8K TVs in the market this year, joining LG, Samsung and others. Just when you think a TV picture is as good as it gets, along comes a new technology with better dynamic range, deeper blacks, higher contrast and more detail. After covering CES for a few decades I have those latest and greatest TV press releases down nearly verbatim. Marketing aside, I remember when I first saw HD, and it floored me. Seeing is believing, and Iâm missing out this year on seeing 8K, the new features of NextGenTV and demonstrations of the latest game players on cutting-edge low-latency TVs. Itâs not surprising artificial intelligence is a big theme at CES 2021. Weâve been living artificially since March, when the pandemic began to rage, pushing us away from our day-to-day office and school lives into an artificial reality where almost all our school, work and entertainment activities are enabled by electronics behind a plate of glass. LG refreshed its OLED TVs this year in the Evo line that boasts âpowerful upscalingâ and âdeep learning.â A feature called AI Picture Pro uses a light sensor to measure ambient light. Then the TVâs processor adjusts tone mapping for optimal screen brightness to âtransform darker scenes into ones with stunning contrast, detail, and color depth.â Thatâs something else I want to see for myself. There have been a lot of whizbang TV features over the years that have promised to make TV pictures âamazing,â âbetter-than-real,â âbreathtakingââ¦. A lot havenât turned out that way. Take, for instance, motion smoothing, known by different marketing terms like TruMotion, Action Smoothing and Motionflow. The technology removes artifacts such as blurring from sports events using interpolation, which is good, but when youâre watching movies, it replaces the dimensionality of film with the sharper look of a soap-opera which isnât good. Some TV makers â including LG, Samsung and Vizio â have adopted as an option Filmmaker Mode, jointly developed by filmmakers, studios, TV makers and UHD Alliance. The feature disables post-processing tweaks like motion smoothing and preserves correct aspect ratios, colors and frame rates. It gives you the option to strip AI out when you donât want it. I see that as a win-win. Other AI at CES: Samsung pushed its fitness app in press events, showing homebound consumers working out to a virtual trainer thatâs part of the Samsung Health app on premium TVs (You bring your own webcam). The trainer works with your smartphone to count reps and critique your form. The app includes workouts, and itâs not just a computer checking your style: the company worked with pro trainers to create the programs. Though Iâm impressed by the tech, I wonât be connecting a camera to my TV. On top of that, the robots are coming, and Iâm really not ready for that. Itâs close enough quarters here with two adults and a couple of felines in a 750-square-foot Manhattan apartment. Thereâs no room for a Jetsonâs Rosie, picking up glassware and emptying the dishwasher. That, apparently is Samsungâs vision for the ânot-too-distant future,â where its AI engine rules the roost. Between Alexa, Google Assistant and Siri, I have enough AI monitoring my life. Samsung is starting small this year, bringing a robot vac bot to the U.S. IRobot launched that category a number of years ago, terrorizing cats all over the world. Now Samsung is bringing JetBot 90 AI+, which packs a camera and lots of AI. I like the idea that it can discern between a dust bunny and a USB-C cable, but Iâm not crazy about an appliance with eyes scurrying around the floor. It isnât just the big guys making AI noise at CES. A startup called Noopl showed a smartphone accessory designed to help you hear clearly based on where youâre looking. The Noopl device plugs into an iPhoneâs lightning port and has three MEMS mics that work with an app to perform audio signal processing. It works with a spatial audio feature in the AirPods Pro to track your head, reduce background noise and focus on the person youâre talking to. That means it knows where youâre looking. Yeah, I dunno. Apple knows a lot more than I want it to already, so itâs a nope to Noopl. Artificial intelligence and an artificial CES. Meh. Give me the bells and whistles, Sin City and larger-than-life TV, but throw in a foot massage, too.
